key_issues: Trademark infringement by the defendants through the use of the "RPG" word mark without authorization from the plaintiff.
Passing off of goods and services by the defendants as those of the plaintiff, potentially causing confusion among consumers.
Copyright infringement by the defendants through the unauthorized use of the plaintiff's registered copyright, the RPG Enterprises Logo (Label).
Use of a deceptively similar trade name by the defendants, "M/s RPG Developers", with the intent to misrepresent an association with the plaintiff.
Registration of domain names and websites by the defendants that incorporate the plaintiff's trademark, potentially causing dilution of the mark.
Alleged intent by the defendants to benefit from the goodwill and reputation associated with the plaintiff's well-known trademarks.
Potential violation of Section 2(1)(zg) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, which recognizes the plaintiff's "RPG" marks as well-known trademarks.
Infringement of the plaintiff's exclusive rights as the registered proprietor of the "RPG" marks in various classes under the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
Potential damage to the plaintiff's business and reputation due to the defendants' unauthorized use of the plaintiff's trademarks and copyright.
Breach of the plaintiff's rights under the Trade Marks Act, 1999, and the Copyright Act, which provide protection against infringement and passing off.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Background:**
The case involves a trademark and copyright infringement dispute between M/s RPG Enterprises Limited (the plaintiff) and RPG Developers Private Limited and its director, Mr. Rampal Goswami (the defendants). The plaintiff is an Indian industrial conglomerate that has been using the "RPG" word mark since 1979 and has registered trademarks in various classes under the Trade Marks Act, 1999. The defendants, on the other hand, are engaged in the selling and renting of properties in India and have been using the "RPG" mark in their business name and promotional materials.

**Legal Issues:**
The plaintiff alleged that the defendants' use of the "RPG" mark constitutes trademark infringement, passing off, and copyright infringement. The plaintiff claimed that its "RPG" marks have acquired the status of well-known trademarks and that the defendants' use of the mark is likely to cause confusion among the public. The plaintiff also alleged that the defendants' actions are intended to misrepresent their association with the plaintiff.

**Arguments:**
The plaintiff argued that the defendants' use of the "RPG" mark is unauthorized and infringing, and that it has caused damage to the plaintiff's reputation and business. The plaintiff relied on its prior use and registration of the "RPG" mark, as well as its reputation and goodwill, to support its claim. The plaintiff also submitted that the defendants' failure to respond to cease and desist notices and their continued use of the infringing mark demonstrate their intent to infringe the plaintiff's rights.

The defendants did not respond to the suit or appear in court, despite being served with notice.

**Court Findings:**
The court found that the plaintiff has established a prima facie case of trademark infringement and passing off. The court noted that the plaintiff's "RPG" marks are well-known and have been registered in various classes, and that the defendants' use of the mark is likely to cause confusion among the public. The court also found that the defendants' actions are intended to misrepresent their association with the plaintiff.

**Decision:**
The court granted an ex parte ad interim injunction in favor of the plaintiff, restraining the defendants from using the "RPG" mark. The court ordered the defendants to stop selling or offering for sale their projects under the "RPG" mark, recall their finished infringing goods and promotional materials, and give an undertaking not to infringe the plaintiff's marks in the future. The court's decision was based on the plaintiff's prior use and registration of the "RPG" mark, as well as the defendants' unauthorized and infringing use of the mark.

**Conclusion:**
The court's decision in this case highlights the importance of protecting intellectual property rights, particularly in cases where a well-known trademark is involved. The court's finding that the defendants' use of the "RPG" mark constitutes trademark infringement and passing off demonstrates the need for businesses to ensure that their use of trademarks does not infringe the rights of others. The case also underscores the importance of responding to cease and desist notices and taking prompt action to remedy any infringement.

The matter was thereafter placed before the Joint Registrar for

6. 
Even though the defendant no.4 was served through ordinary mode on 
17th February, 2018, none appeared for the defendant no.4 on 16th March, 
2018, 9th May, 2018 and 15th May, 2018. Further, no written statement was 
filed on behalf of the defendant no.4. Consequently, the defendant no.4 was 
proceeded against ex parte on 15th May, 2018. 
7. 
Fresh service of summons was directed for the defendants no.1 to 3 
and 5 on 3rd March, 2020 and 22nd September, 2021  
8. 
On 12th January, 2022, the counsel for the plaintiff submitted that all 
the defendants, with the exception of the defendant no.4, have been duly 
served and that an affidavit of service has also been filed in this regard. 
9.

defendants no.1 to 3 and 5 to file written statement and the matter was 
placed before the Court.  
11. 
In view of the above, the counsel for the plaintiff prays for a decree of 
permanent injunction and damages along with costs in the suit. 
ANALYSIS AND FINDINGS 
12. 
I have heard the counsel for the plaintiff and perused the record of the 
case. 
13. 
At the outset, it may be relevant to note that the defendants no.1 to 3 
and 5 has been served through speed post, courier and email. Despite this, 
the defendants no.1 to 3 and 5 have chosen not to enter appearance. The 
defendant no.4 has also been proceeded against ex parte on 15th May, 2018. 
Ample opportunity has been given to the defendants to appear before the 
Court and defend the case. 
14. 
Since the defendants have failed to enter appearance or even take any 
steps requisite to contest the present suit, despite having suffered an ad 
interim injunction order, it is evident that they have no defence to put forth 
on merits.  
15. 
At this stage, it may be relevant to note the comparison between the

At this stage, counsel for the plaintiff does not press for the reliefs

20. 
Insofar as the relief of damages as sought in prayer clause „f.‟ is

DEVELOPERS‟ in order to dupe the general public into believing that the 
defendants are a subsidiary/group company/joint venture of the plaintiff,

Projects of the defendants are being listed on their website using the „RPG‟

The plaintiff, M/s RPG Enterprises Limited, sought a permanent injunction to restrain the defendants, RPG Developers Private Limited and others, from infringing their trademarks and copyrights.

The plaintiff, an Indian industrial conglomerate, has been using the "RPG" word mark since 1979 and is the proprietor of registered trademarks in various classes. The marks have been registered in foreign countries as well and have acquired the status of well-known trademarks. The plaintiff is also the registered copyright owner of the RPG Enterprises Logo (Label) and owns domain names "www.rpggroup.com" and "www.rpg.in".

The defendant, RPG Developers Private Limited, is a company engaged in selling and renting properties in India, with Mr. Rampal Goswami as its director. The plaintiff alleged that the defendants were infringing their trademarks and copyrights, and sought relief, including a permanent injunction.

The court, presided over by Hon'ble Mr. Justice Amit Bansal, heard the case, but the defendants were not represented. The judgment, delivered orally, is recorded in the PDF document, which provides details of the case, including pleadings, facts, and arguments. (Source: 2022/DHC/005847, CS(COMM) 21/2018, Pages 1-7 of the PDF document)

According to the PDF document "RPG ENTERPRISES LIMITED VS. RPG DEVELOPERS PRIVATE LIMITED.pdf", a lawsuit (CS(COMM) 21/2018) was filed in the High Court of Delhi. The plaintiff, M/S RPG Enterprises Limited, alleged trademark infringement and passing off by the defendants, RPG Developers Private Limited. 

The court granted an interim injunction order on December 21, 2022, restraining the defendants from using the registered trademark "RPG" and any similar marks. The defendants were served with summons multiple times, but they failed to appear or file a written statement. Consequently, the court proceeded against them ex parte.

The plaintiff prayed for a decree of permanent injunction, damages, and costs. After analyzing the case, the court found that the defendants had no defense to put forth on merits, despite being given ample opportunity to appear and contest the suit.

The court compared the plaintiff's mark with the defendants' mark and found similarities. The lawsuit highlights the importance of protecting intellectual property rights, particularly trademarks. The case is a reminder that failure to defend oneself in court can lead to adverse decisions.

Key dates in the case include:
- February 17, 2018: Defendant no.4 was served through ordinary mode.
- May 15, 2018: Defendant no.4 was proceeded against ex parte.
- December 6, 2022: The Joint Registrar closed the right of the defendants to file a written statement.
- December 21, 2022: The court granted an interim injunction order.

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "RPG ENTERPRISES LIMITED VS. RPG DEVELOPERS PRIVATE LIMITED.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi made a decision on December 21, 2022, in the case CS(COMM) 21/2018. The plaintiff, M/S RPG ENTERPRISES LIMITED, sued the defendants, RPG DEVELOPERS PRIVATE LIMITED, for allegedly misusing the "RPG" mark owned by the plaintiff. 

The court found that the defendants had failed to respond to legal notices sent on August 10, 2017, and had also chosen not to participate in the proceedings despite being served. The court determined that this was not a case of innocent adoption, but rather a flagrant misuse of the plaintiff's marks by the defendants.

As a result, the court decreed the suit in favor of the plaintiff, awarding Rs.3,00,000/- as damages and an additional Rs.3,00,000/- as costs to be paid by the defendants. The defendants were given eight weeks to pay the amount, failing which the plaintiff could commence execution proceedings against them. All pending applications were disposed of, and a decree sheet was to be drawn up. The decision was made by Judge Amit Bansal on December 21, 2022, and digitally signed on December 24, 2022. (Source: 2022/DHC/005847, RPG ENTERPRISES LIMITED VS. RPG DEVELOPERS PRIVATE LIMITED.pdf)
